turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Under the -- under the -- under a long line of -- of ruling is in accordance and the Commission.
As a matter of fact you can reach it two ways.

One, the absence of incendiary -- of essential parts doesn't affect its character and the second is analog -- the rule of analogy, it's more nearly analogous to an incendiary bomb than it is to an empty bomb.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, was this -- is this anymore explosive than -- I think someone asked you that question, I'm not sure, they're just plain gasoline?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Well it -- it -- burns much more fiercely.
It burns (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it more explosive and more incendiary, more easier to explode?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: But I would say probably about the same except there may not be that the -- the fumes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, what's -- what's the rate on gasoline?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: The rate on gasoline I think is fifth-class and the rate on napalm powder is fifth-class and the rate on -- on the empty cases is fifth-class, none constant that the rate on the combination which has the characteristic of an entity should be fifth-class also.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That -- that -- that's the difference.
I'm just trying to get what it is --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- the real difference here.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.
Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It is that even though this might not be within the classification of being more incendiary explosives and gasoline nevertheless, under the practice and the classification is to be treated as an incendiary bomb within the meaning of 1800.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: That's right.
Yes.

And -- and that's perfectly clear and -- and if -- if that is thought to be an -- an unreasonable rate, the way was open but the way to -- the way to deal with unreasonable rates is not to have the Comptroller General say it that the combination rule applies when it doesn't.
I mean against that kind of administrative arbitrariness the carrier is entitled to resort to a court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You haven't discussed one thing and I -- I don't like to interrupt you but I am interested in it and I -- I don't understand it fully yet, I don't understand the answer.
If the Government is given six years in which to file this suit --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: The carrier I think, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The carrier and the Government can be sued at anytime within six years, actually action motive, why -- on what basis should the Government be denied the right to offset or to set up as a defense or to recoup or whatever it is, if -- if a suit is actually brought against it even though the two years for bringing an affirmative action has expired?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Because this Court and the Commission have said for many, many years going back to about 1910 that the limitation for going to the Commission on a claim of unreasonableness bars the power of the Commission.

Now, it may be -- it may be that that is something Congress ought to look in to but here for -- for nearly 50 years its been held without even a recorded dissenting vote that this is jurisdiction, it bars the power of the Commission.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I understand but --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you this?
Has there been any case yet that passed on this point?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.
The -- I would say the Morrisdale case from the 230th of U.S. have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You think it held that you cannot set it up as a defense?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.
When it -- when you -- when it come --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even though it arises out of the same transaction and it's purely --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: That's our precise case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the Morrisdale.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Morrisdale case, 230 U.S. --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that the only case?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: That's the only case I know of but it has never been questioned and it was explained later on in the footnote as saying, “Well, no reference was ordered there because no rights could be saved thereby.
The reason being at the time had expired and the Commission was powerless to do anything about it.”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Morrisdale?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Morrisdale Coal Company against the Pennsylvania, 230 U.S.204 at 214 to 215.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If the Government here knows that the railroad should claim these bombs that come under -- what is it 1840?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did the Government -- I'm going to --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If the Government know that tariff 1820, isn't it?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When was that filed originally?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Oh, I don't know, it hasn't changed much.
I mean it's filed and re-filed but I -- it's -- it's been -- it was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But what I want to know if the Government have means of contesting a known claim by the railroad that that tariff covers these kind of bombs in ample time to protect itself against claims by the Commission, a collection by the Commission which would be barred --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.

I -- I think the answer is “yes” because the bills, the carrier's bills which are in the record show the shipment of so and so many crates of incendiary bombs, NP1 without bursters or fuses and was billed in item 1 --1820.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As of what date?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Back in 1944 when the shipments were made.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well then, the Government then and there, from your point of view to the broader proceeding before the Commission, challenging the reasonableness of that rate and seeking to have it declared unreasonableness -- unreasonable insofar as apply to this kind of commodity?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, may I ask you this in that connection because this gets to a little more than just I think, of claims decision on cases heretofore.
The Government did know, we'll say that there had been cases it held that it had to sue within two years.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Beginning at 80 I.C.C.-- U.S. v. Director General in 80 I.C.C.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.
But the Government knew that it -- the Government that the railroad had not filed any suit, had it notified the Government that it was going to try to collect the -- I -- I presume (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Well in -- in -- in all --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The Government doesn't file suits because it would take it as -- acquiesced it.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: In -- in all three cases, the carriers billed the Government at the higher rate.
In the Western Pacific case, the Government paid at the lower rate.
In Bangor and Aroostook and Seaboard the Government paid at the higher rate and then sometime later the Comptroller General made or authorized deductions against subsequent bills.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well that -- that raises a different question.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Litigants put it up in different --

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- different charges.

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: But -- but under the -- under the Saint Louis and Brownsville, the mere fact of waiting for the period of limitations does not constitute gross acquiescence so as to bar the carrier.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Either four or five Union Pacific case, which is the one that you referred in the so-called stipulation?

turn.speaker: frederick_bernays_wiener
turn.label: Mr. Frederick Bernays Wiener
turn.text: 125 Court of Claims, I think its 393.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Hollander, I asked Colonel Wiener, what was the date of the deduction made by the Government and how long thereafter was it before the railroad company filed its lawsuit?
Do you know those dates?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Your Honor, there are three cases involved in this litigation.
In the first case, Western Pacific, there were no deductions.
The Government was billed in 1948 and in 1950 at the high first class rate.
The Government paid promptly the lower fifth-class rate in 1948 and in 1950.
Suit was filed by the carrier in 1954, four years after the latest payment and six years after the earliest payment.
And the other two cases of Bangor and Aroostook and Seaboard, all of the shipments took place in 1944.

The suit was filed by the carrier in 1954 but in that -- in those two cases the Government did as Colonel Wiener has pointed out, did pay the carriers originally in 1944 at the higher first class rate.

Later the G.A.O. it's only in these two cases that the G.A.O. took any action of -- the G.A.O. did make a deduction when, the record is not indicated whether it was within two years prior to 1954 or within six years prior to 1954 that those deductions were effected and those two cases the record does not show.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The Government paid promptly in the Aroostook and the Seaboard?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is to say in 1944 (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
In 1944, they've paid at the higher first class rate promptly then they exercised the statutory right to recoupment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The shipment was in 1944 when the payments were made?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes., Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Hollander, are these deductions made by the Government under this permissive act isolated instances or does it happen as a matter of daily routine, do you know?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I -- I don't know the -- the answer to that question, Your Honor.
I don't know what the percentage of cases in which it is necessary for the Government to exercise this right of recoupment.

Actually this is really a provision that the carriers were insisting on putting in the 1940 Transportation Act because before that time the carriers did not get prompt payment, they had to wait until final audit by the General Accounting Office that they complained took too long a period.
They were able to persuade Congress to require the Government to pay promptly, even if the Government had some doubt as to the appropriate classification.
And then the carriers told the Government, “Well, G.A.O. can come at anytime it wants to in post audit and we'll even make a refund or you can deduct.”
And that's precisely what happened in the Transportation Act of 1940.

Congress directed the Government whenever it gets a carrier bill to pay it promptly then if -- then if you want to, if you have these hundreds of thousands of vouchers, bills of lading to examine that did accumulate during the war then the G.A.O. could examine those -- those vouchers in their due course and make the necessary deduction whenever they finally reach that particular stack of vouchers.

What the -- what the respondents really are asking for here by insisting that we go to the Interstate Commerce Commission within two years by saying that we slipped in our rights by not going to the Interstate Commerce Commission within two years.

What they're really trying to do is to strip the Government completely of the post audit protection, Congress expressly reserved to it in this Transportation Act of 1940 as consideration for this prompt payment that the Government was required to make to the carriers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, you would admit, don't you that the I.C.C. is a more informed body to determine what classification tariff, what classification apply to the General Accounting Office.

The Government thinks that -- that a bill that is presented and under these classification with all -- with all great respect to that on (Inaudible) offer, General Accounting Office are usually the I.C.C. the better place to fight this out than General Accounting.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, I -- I agree, Your Honor.
That certainly on the reasonableness question it is.
But the fact that -- the fact that Congress entrusted the G.A.O. with this right to make a -- the initial deduction that that certainly leaks the view from a reading of the Transportation Act --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't question what Congress has ordered --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: And -- and the -- the Government notwithstanding the First Circuit decision that Colonel Wiener relies on, the -- the Government is never before had to establish the correctness of the deduction or the illegality of an overpayment before these deductions are effected.

That was true before the Transportation Act in 252 U.S., Justice Brandeis's writing for a unanimous court and that has been the law ever since right through the Transportation Act of 1940, he pointed in a -- a case very closely important because in that case the -- the Government had the carrier claimed underpaid it and by virtue of the fact that the Government in 1912 had effected the deductions against the carriers' account for the prior 12-year period.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Mr. Hollander are you going to say anything more about the Morrisdale case?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I'd like very much, Your Honor if I may to address myself to that case.

But I was just about to say, Your Honor, that in this justice -- in Justice Brandeis's case, the Government -- it was the Government's right to effect these deductions in 1912, was attacked and Justice Brandeis bluntly rejected the argument that the Government has to come in first into Court or before a committee to establish the legality of the deductions or the illegality of the overpayment.
Now, Morrisdale, Your Honor, we feel is -- is not at all even in point in this case.
It is not true that Morrisdale in response to Mr. Justice Black's question precluded the consideration of a defense asserted by this shipper.
That, Your Honor, is not true.
Morrisdale -- Morrisdale typifies the situation where a plaintiff or a claimant having an affirmative claim has an opportunity to go before an administrative tribunal within a fixed period of time.
He let's that fixed period of time go by, the right --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: That's -- that's true to here.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well here -- here, Your Honor, the people who let the fixed period of time go by originally was the carrier, the plaintiff --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not under six -- not if the -- not if the six-year rule prevail.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You can't blow hot and cold on this.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: No.
I -- I certainly realized that and I don't want to attempt to.
I would like to point out however though that in Morrisdale, the situation was this.
The -- the shipper in that case filed suit in the District Court.
He had no business under the Abilene case.He had no business even filing that suit in the District Court until he had theretofore obtained an I.C.C. determination.
That -- that there are no -- no question in that case.
He had no right to go into Court in to the primary jurisdiction until he had obtained the I.C.C. determination.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He didn't know --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: He had little --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- how the courts decided that.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, the Court -- the Court -- the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He didn't know that until the Court decided that.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: The Court's opinion indicates that he should've been wiser before their decision.
The -- the shipper in that case left a period of time go by.
He had two years to go before the I.C.C.
The shipper left that period of time go by.
He let's the two year period of time go by and then he comes into Court and the Court says, “Well, what you should have gone first to the I.C.C. and you let that period of time go by.
We're not going to let you come into Court now after the two-year period of time in which you could have gone to Commission has gone by.”

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you -- could you not have gone to the Commission to just prove the reasonableness of this rate?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
There was no need.
There was no what.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, let me tell you why, Your Honor.

In the Western Pacific case for example, we take promptly in 1948 and in 1950 on the basis of the lower fifth-class rates and so far as the record in this case is concerned -- so far as the record in this case is concerned that it was paid -- complete at that time.
The -- the account was settled.

We did not know until six years later in 1954 that when suit was filed in the Court of Claims that our -- a deduction was being -- that our alleged underpayment was being attacked by the carrier and we would have been thrown out, I think, it's quite properly so by the Interstate Commerce --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That wasn't true --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: -- Commission if we had gone as so prematurely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That wasn't true of Bangor and Aroostook I gather?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: In Bangor and Aroostook, Your Honor, in Seaboard I think there are even more decisive considerations militating against the possibility of the Government going to the Interstate Commerce Commission within two years after 1944 because if as I had pointed out before the Government is required to go to the Interstate Commerce Commission within two years after 1944 that means that that statutory reservation of post audit protection is completely thrown out of the window its -- its been made meaningless.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As I understand this deduction was made the same year?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
In the Western -- in the Bangor and Aroostook and in Seaboard, the record is silent as to when the deductions were effective.

All we know is that prompt payment of the higher amount was made at the carriers' request in 1954, a deduction was made sometime in the next 10 year period of time and at the end of that 10 year period of time in 1954 the carrier comes into Court and files this suit.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But, if you had -- if the Government has gone, I take it you're in an (Inaudible), aren't you?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
If I assume I'm not using the time of that case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Had not heard that yet.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's what they (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, I thought in that wherever we represent --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I thought it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I've just -- just the same question now, is it?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But we're still in this, I've got a question I'd like to ask in this case for within it?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In this -- in this case, would you have been thrown out if you've brought up an action for the I.C.C. saying the Government has billed us at a rate on a wrong class on -- they claim this is the classification and we think that this is an unreasonable classification.
Would you have been thrown out by the I.C.C.on 1945 or 1944?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, Your Honor there -- first of all, Your Honor, there -- there was no basis.
Actually, I don't know where in the Government we -- we --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't that a bill presented on the -- under the -- first on --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Congress?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- classification.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
But in 1940, Congress said at the carriers' request they told us, Congress told the Government, “Now look, you get those bills, pay them.
Pay them on presentation.
That's the way the statute reads.”
All right.
We pay those bills on presentation.
They go over to G.A.O.
G.A.O.'s machinery has to start to function.

As I say they were -- the -- an enormous amount of bills naturally accumulating during the world war period when there were so, so many thousands, hundreds of thousands of shipment of military supplies over to domestic carriers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you know what the carriers' position was and the carrier isn't going to render you a bill and the next they change his mind, is it?
What I want to know -- (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, I don't know, Your Honor.
I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I want to know is whether the I.C.C. had jurisdiction to entertain a suit, a proceeding by -- by the shipper with the United States or any other shipper saying, this tariff is unreasonable.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I think -- I think -- they all -- I -- I can only answer, Your Honor, in this way.

I take it was imperfectly justifiable for the I.C.C. to throw us out and to tell us, “Now look, you have the statutory right reserved to you in the Transportation Act in 1940 to effect the deduction of any amount you claim is unfair.”

Now, you exercise that right and then come running to us if again any difficulty but if you are able to settle this through the -- through the exercise of this explicitly reserved right well than -- than of course --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You think -- you think if I have been under the Interstate Commerce Commission I could have said to you no mater what the General Accounting Office judge, they can't determine the relevant and reasonable tariff.
That's the business with the permission with oversight by the Court.
You don't think I could have said that instead of course that I won't take it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Hollander, two of these cases, the railroad charged the low-rate didn't it?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: No -- no, Your Honor.
In all three cases the record shows that the railroad --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh, I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: -- did demand a higher rate.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The higher rate.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: But in --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you this then that's (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: But we paid in two of the -- in the Western Pacific case --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: We paid initially the lower rate.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
May I ask you this?

Bearing upon the question of reasonableness as to the Government going to the Interstate Commerce Commission to ask advice on each one of these deductions, do you think you could get for us a number of deductions that were made say since --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of the present time since these cases --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I'm sure --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- since these shipments were made --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I be delighted to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- just so we know --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: -- furnish a supplemental memorandum --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
If you will please.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: -- to show the (Voice Overlap) the burden under which G.A.O. operated.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: May I, Your Honor, have the Court's indulgence to answer Mr. Justice Harlan's question?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
If it -- has your question been answered?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, I thought of that and maybe there's one little at that point.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, I -- I wanted to distinguish that Morrisdale --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I think we better get on to the next case now.
It's in your brief I take Mr. Hollander?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Oh, yes, Your Honor, we're content to rely on the distinctions in the brief.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I would like to ask you --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- why -- why did you pay the lower rate on Western Pacific case?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Why did we, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: When the Congress have told you to pay the --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, the -- the answer to that, Your Honor, is that by the time 1948 law, these shipments took place in the Korean conflict in Western Pacific.
The -- the shipments in the other two cases took place in World War II.

By the time the shipments in Korean conflict took place in 1948 and 1950 the administrative agency, the War Department of the Army had already been alert as to the fact that the carriers were charging the higher first class rates for these good which should have been shipped at the relatively lower fifth-class rates.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: So, the problem had already been aired, it was a matter of common knowledge and it was possible -- it was possible for the -- for the Army to -- to realize what the true situation was at the time of presentation in the bills and the record shows that they were paid promptly, its just that they were able to cash the error in the bill before it was processed administratively.
It never did go on to the G.A.O. where any post (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not -- not until they told you to pay the higher amount --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: No.
That they told us only --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: They told us only, Your Honor, to pay promptly on presentation before audit by the General Accounting Office and that -- that mandate was complied with in order with the pay system and there hasn't been any challenged that we pay promptly prior to audit by the G.A.O.
